required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Internal Jugular Vein Cross Sectional Area
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Position on Cross Sectional Area of IJV

brief_summary.textblock: The Trendelenburg position is used to distend the central veins, improving both success and safety of vascular cannulation. The purpose of this study is to measure the cross-sectional area of the internal jugular vein (IJV) in three different positions, using surface ultrasound.

primary_outcome.measure: Effect of trendelenburg and reverse trendelenburg position on the cross sectional area of the internal jugular vein
primary_outcome.time_frame: At time of data collection: physiologic study
primary_outcome.description: There will be substantial anatomic variation in venous size. Further, Trendelenburg positioning will have little impact on venous cross-sectional area in most subjects when compared with supine.

study_pop.textblock: Patients admitted to Intensive care unit.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adult medical or surgical ICU patients who have preexisting central venous (jugular/subclavian only) catheters.
Exclusion Criteria:
- subjects with only a femoral venous catheter.
- subjects whose CVP measurement by the indwelling catheter exceeds 20cm of water.
- subjects younger than 18 years old.
- inability to obtain informed consent from the subject or the subjects authorized representative.

overall_official.affiliation: Roy J. & Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine, University of Iowa

reference.citation: Bazaral M, Harlan S. Ultrasonographic anatomy of the internal jugular vein relevant to percutaneous cannulation. Crit Care Med. 1981 Apr;9(4):307-10.

Vinayak AG, Levitt J, Gehlbach B, Pohlman AS, Hall JB, Kress JP. Usefulness of the external jugular vein examination in detecting abnormal central venous pressure in critically ill patients. Arch Intern Med. 2006 Oct 23;166(19):2132-7.

responsible_party.organization: Roy J. & Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine, University of Iowa
